pageProps.body:
Net Change and Future Value

Everything we have said about velocity, position, and displacement carries over to more general situations. Suppose you are interested in some quantity QQQ that changes over time; QQQ may represent the amount of water in a reservoir, the population of a cell culture, or the amount of a resource that is consumed or produced. If you are given the rate Q′Q'Q′ at which QQQ changes, then integration allows you to calculate either the net change in the quantity QQQ or the future value of QQQ.

We argue just as we did for Velocity and Position: Because Q(t)Q(t)Q(t) is an antiderivative of Q′(t)Q\prime(t)Q′(t), the Fundamental Theorem tells us that

∫abQ′(t)dt=Q(b)−Q(a)=net change in Q over [a,b]\int_a^b{Q\prime(t)}{dt}=Q(b)-Q(a)=\text{net change in Q over [a,b]}∫ab​Q′(t)dt=Q(b)−Q(a)=net change in Q over [a,b]

Geometrically, this net change is the net area under the graph of Q′Q\primeQ′ over [a,b][a,b][a,b]. We interpret the product Q′(t)Q\prime(t)Q′(t) as the change in QQQ over a small increment of time.

Alternatively, given both the rate of change Q′Q\primeQ′ and the initial value Q(0)Q(0)Q(0), integrating over the interval [0,t][0,t][0,t], where t≥0t\geq0t≥0, we can use

∫0tQ′(x)dx=Q(t)−Q(0)\int_0^t{Q\prime(x)}{dx}=Q(t)-Q(0)∫0t​Q′(x)dx=Q(t)−Q(0)

Rearranging this equation, we write the value of QQQ at any future time t≥0t\geq0t≥0 as

Q(t)=Q(0)+∫0tQ′(x)dxQ(t)=Q(0)+\int_0^t{Q\prime(x)}{dx}Q(t)=Q(0)+∫0t​Q′(x)dx

Net change and future value

Suppose a quantity QQQ changes over time at a known rate Q′Q\primeQ′. Then the net change in QQQ between t=at=at=a and t=b>at=b>at=b>a is

∫0tQ′(x)dx=Q(t)−Q(0)\int_0^t{Q\prime(x)}{dx}=Q(t)-Q(0)∫0t​Q′(x)dx=Q(t)−Q(0)

Given the initial value Q(0)Q(0)Q(0), the future value of QQQ at time t≥0t\geq0t≥0 is

Q(t)=Q(0)+∫0tQ′(x)dxQ(t)=Q(0)+\int_0^t{Q\prime(x)}{dx}Q(t)=Q(0)+∫0t​Q′(x)dx

Correspondences between velocity-displacement problems and more general problems:

Velocity-Displacement ProblemsGeneral Problems
Position s(t)s(t)s(t)Quantity Q(t)Q(t)Q(t) (such as volume or population size)
Velocity: s′(t)=v(t)s\prime(t)=v(t)s′(t)=v(t)Rate of change: Q′(t)Q\prime(t)Q′(t)
Displacement: s(b)−s(a)=∫abv(t)dts(b)-s(a)=\int_a^b{v(t)}{dt}s(b)−s(a)=∫ab​v(t)dtNet change: Q(b)−Q(a)=∫abQ′(t)dtQ(b)-Q(a)=\int_a^b{Q\prime(t)}{dt}Q(b)−Q(a)=∫ab​Q′(t)dt
Future Position: s(t)=s(0)+∫0tv(x)dxs(t)=s(0)+\int_0^t{v(x)}{dx}s(t)=s(0)+∫0t​v(x)dxFuture value of QQQ: Q(t)=Q(0)+∫0tQ′(x)dxQ(t)=Q(0)+\int_0^t{Q\prime(x)}{dx}Q(t)=Q(0)+∫0t​Q′(x)dx
